examples.english: The book is on the table

etymology.notes: From Latin casa meaning a simple dwelling
From Latin tempus, related to English temporal
From Latin homo (stem homin-), root of English human, humane
From Latin diurnus, related to English diurnal
From Latin vita, root of English vital, vitamin
From Latin manus, cognate with English manual, manipulate
From Latin mundus, originally meaning clean, pure
From Latin oculus, root of English ocular, oculist

examples.english: I drink a lot of water

etymology.notes: Direct from Latin aqua, cognate with English aquatic
From Latin panis, root of English pantry, company (com-panis)
From Latin domina, feminine of dominus (lord, master)
From Italian bambo (simpleton), possibly of onomatopoeic origin
From Latin pagensis, from pagus (country district)
From Latin civitas, root of English civic, citizen
From Latin strata (via), meaning paved road

examples.english: I go to work by car

etymology.notes: From Latin familia, root of English family
From Greek/Latin -icus suffix, meaning "relating to" or "characteristic of". Cognate with English -ic.
From Latin labor, root of English labor, laboratory
From Latin schola, from Greek σχολή meaning leisure
From Latin denarius (coin worth ten asses), root of English monetary
From Latin pars (stem part-), related to English part
From Latin persona, originally meaning theatrical mask
From Greek ἱστορία, from historein (to inquire)
From Latin liber, originally meaning tree bark used for writing
From Latin porta, related to English portal, port
From Latin mare, root of English marine, maritime
From Latin sol, root of English solar, solstice
From Latin luna, root of English lunar, lunacy
From Latin terra, root of English terrestrial, territory
From Latin focus, originally meaning hearth
From Latin russus, variant of ruber (red)
From Latin niger, related to English negative
From Germanic blank, cognate with English blank
From Latin grandis, root of English grand, grandiose
Possibly from Latin piculus, diminutive form
From Latin novus, cognate with English novel, novice
From Latin vetulus, diminutive of vetus (old)
From Latin bonus, cognate with English bonus
From Latin bellus, related to English belle, beauty
From Latin -bilis suffix, meaning "able to be" or "worthy of". Cognate with English -ble suffix.
